importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article reflects the current state of food supply operations to Gaza, highlighting the urgency of humanitarian aid delivery amid ongoing conflict and ceasefire conditions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline reflects the immediate post-ceasefire period, during which humanitarian access and food distribution are being evaluated and scaled up.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza remain far below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara — are currently operational, limiting aid delivery.
The WFP has 26 distribution points open in Gaza, up from five, but still short of the goal of 145 distribution points.
The US-brokered ceasefire and Donald Trump’s 20-point plan are central to enabling sustained humanitarian access.
Humanitarian aid is still not reaching northern Gaza, and the main Salah al-Din Street remains closed due to security concerns.
Hamas has pledged to hand over 28 captives' bodies, having delivered 13 so far, which is tied to the reopening of Rafah crossing.
Residents are rationing food due to fear of renewed conflict and supply shortages, storing food for emergency use.
Food supplies currently feed about half a million people for two weeks, indicating a severe shortfall in long-term relief.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating global food aid operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is directly involved in assessing and reporting on food supply levels in Gaza, highlighting the humanitarian crisis and urging increased access to aid corridors.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing into Gaza from Israel, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two active crossings allowing food supplies into Gaza, and its functionality is critical to meeting humanitarian needs.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim in Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing into Gaza from Israel, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two active crossings enabling food delivery, and its operation is essential for increasing food supply to Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its closure restricts access to northern Gaza and is dependent on Hamas fulfilling a prisoner exchange agreement, delaying humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south road in Gaza, currently closed to WFP operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted access to use this route, limiting distribution to southern and central Gaza and excluding northern areas.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered a ceasefire and proposed a 20-point plan for Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role in mediating the ceasefire and outlining a plan for full humanitarian aid access makes him central to the current peace and aid strategy.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who stated the Rafah crossing remains closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His statement on the Rafah crossing closure directly influences access to northern Gaza, affecting humanitarian reach and distribution.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and militant group that has agreed to release captives in exchange for reopening crossings.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is central to the prisoner exchange process, which is a prerequisite for reopening key crossings like Rafah and for sustained humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas, responsible for announcing the exhumation and handover of Israeli captives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It publicly confirms the release of captives, which is a key condition for reopening crossings and restoring humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: US-brokered ceasefire
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A peace agreement mediated by US President Donald Trump.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ceasefire enables the current level of food delivery and is seen as vital for preventing famine and saving lives in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: 20-point plan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A proposal by US President Donald Trump for ending the war in Gaza, including full aid access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The plan provides a framework for full humanitarian access and is the basis for increased aid deliveries, especially via border crossings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically low despite a US-brokered ceasefire, with only 750 tonnes of food entering daily — far below the target of 2,000 tonnes. This is due to only two crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara — being operational, and the closure of the Rafah crossing until Hamas hands over more captives. The WFP has expanded its distribution network to 26 points, still short of the goal of 145, and has not been granted access to key areas like Salah al-Din Street. Residents are rationing food due to fears of renewed conflict, storing supplies for emergencies. The US and Israeli governments are closely linked to the humanitarian access framework, with humanitarian aid delivery dependent on prisoner exchange progress and the full implementation of the 20-point peace plan.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
